title: 111_s3261
content: The "Buffalo Bayou National Heritage Area Act" establishes the Buffalo Bayou National Heritage Area, with defined terms like Heritage Area, management entity, management plan, map, Secretary, and State. The Buffalo Bayou National Heritage Area is established in Harris County, Texas with a designated management entity, the Buffalo Bayou National Heritage Area Corporation. A map of the area will be included in the management plan and available for public inspection. The Secretary, through the management entity, may use funds to make grants, enter agreements, hire staff, obtain money, contract for goods/services, and catalyze activities for the Buffalo Bayou National Heritage Area in Harris County, Texas. The management entity for the Buffalo Bayou National Heritage Area in Harris County, Texas, is responsible for preparing and submitting a management plan to the Secretary. They also assist in carrying out programs and projects, establishing interpretive exhibits, and developing recreational and educational opportunities in the Heritage Area. The management entity for the Buffalo Bayou National Heritage Area in Harris County, Texas is responsible for preparing and submitting a management plan to the Secretary. They also assist in carrying out programs and projects, establishing interpretive exhibits, developing recreational and educational opportunities, increasing public awareness, protecting historic sites, ensuring clear signage, and promoting partnerships within the Heritage Area. Consideration is given to the interests of diverse entities in the area. The management entity in the Buffalo Bayou National Heritage Area assists businesses, organizations, and individuals in preparing and implementing the management plan. They conduct public meetings semiannually and submit annual reports to the Secretary detailing activities, expenses, and income. They also make records available for audit and require agreements for expenditure of Federal funds. The management entity in the Buffalo Bayou National Heritage Area is required to ensure economic viability consistent with the Heritage Area. Federal funds cannot be used to acquire real property, and a 50 percent cost-sharing requirement is mandated for activities funded under this Act. SEC. 5. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The management entity must submit a proposed management plan for the Heritage Area to the Secretary within 3 years of the Act's enactment. The plan should integrate protection, enhancement, and interpretation of natural, cultural, historic, scenic, and recreational resources, consider State and local plans, and include an inventory of resources in the core area. The proposed management plan for the Heritage Area should include comprehensive policies, strategies, and recommendations for conservation, funding, management, and development. It should also describe agreed-upon actions by governments, private organizations, and individuals to protect the natural, historical, and cultural resources of the area. Additionally, the plan should outline implementation actions by the management entity to facilitate collaboration among partners. The management plan for the Heritage Area includes promoting resource protection, restoration, and construction, specific commitments for the first 5 years, identifying funding sources, coordinating local, State, and Federal programs, and developing an interpretive plan. The management plan for the Heritage Area must include an interpretive plan and recommend policies for resource management. If the plan is not submitted within 3 years, the entity will lose funding until it is approved by the Secretary within 180 days. The Secretary, in consultation with the State, must approve or disapprove the management plan within 180 days of receiving it. Approval criteria include diverse representation, public and governmental involvement, and adequate opportunities for input. If the Secretary disapproves the management plan, they must advise the management entity of the reasons, make recommendations for revisions, and approve or disapprove any proposed revision within 180 days. Amendments to the plan can be made as needed. The Secretary must approve or disapprove any substantial amendments to the management plan before federal funds can be used for implementation. SEC. 6. RELATIONSHIP TO OTHER FEDERAL AGENCIES. In general, this Act does not affect the authority of Federal agencies to provide assistance under other laws. Federal agencies planning activities impacting the Heritage Area should consult with the Secretary and management entity. The Act does not modify laws authorizing Federal land management or limit the discretion of Federal land managers within the Heritage Area. SEC. 7. PRIVATE PROPERTY PROTECTION. The Act ensures that property owners' rights are not infringed upon, including the right to abstain from participating in Heritage Area activities, without requiring public access to their property or altering existing land use regulations. It does not grant authority to manage water resources. The Act does not infringe on property owners' rights, including the right to abstain from Heritage Area activities or alter land use regulations. It does not grant authority to manage water resources or diminish the State's authority over fish and wildlife regulation. SEC. 8. WATER RIGHTS. The Act does not modify the Rio Grande Natural Area Act or conflict with the Act of May 31, 1939. It does not authorize regulation of private land in the Heritage Area, impose mandatory streamflow requirements, create Federal water rights, or impose stricter water quality standards. The State of Texas can still acquire instream flow through the Heritage Area under State law. The Act does not authorize regulation of private land in the Heritage Area or impose mandatory streamflow requirements. The State of Texas can still acquire instream flow through the Heritage Area under State law. SEC. 9. EVALUATION REPORT. The Secretary must conduct an evaluation of the Heritage Area's accomplishments and prepare a report before Federal funding ends. The evaluation will assess the management entity's progress in achieving the purposes and goals of the management plan, analyze investments, and review the management structure and partnerships. The Secretary will review the management structure, partnership relationships, and funding of the Heritage Area to identify critical components for sustainability. A report will be prepared with recommendations for the future role of the National Park Service, including an analysis of ways to reduce or eliminate Federal funding if reauthorization is recommended. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress on the recommendations for the future role of the National Park Service, including ways to reduce or eliminate Federal funding. Authorization of $10,000,000 for the Act, with a limit of $1,000,000 per fiscal year. The Secretary's assistance authority under the Act ends 15 years after initial funding.
